clinical_study.brief_title: Active Video-game Playing and Food Intake in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Active Video-game Playing and a Glucose Preload on Food Intake Regulation in Children

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this experiment is to investigate the effect of active video game playing for 30 minutes on food intake and subjective appetite. The investigators hypothesize that video game playing will affect food intake in children. Food intake will be measured at 30 minutes following a glucose (50g glucose in 250ml of water) or sweetened non-caloric (150mg SucraloseÂ® in 250ml of water) beverage with or without active video game playing. Subjective appetite will be measured at 0, 15, 30 and 60 minutes.

primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline and then 15, 30, and 60 minutes after preload consumption
primary_outcome.description: subjective appetite assessed by motivation-to-eat visual analogue scale. The scale range is between 0 and 100 mm. Higher scores represent higher appetite

secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline and then 15, 30, and 60 minutes after preload consumption
secondary_outcome.description: Measured using visual analogue scale (mm). Each VAS is a 100 mm line where they will place a pencil mark to describe their feelings.

healthy boys with no emotional, behavioral or learning problems
